name.text: 12.1.3.2 The tangent line to a curve: exponential

questiontext.text:
Exercise

In this exercise we will find the equation of the tangent line to the curve \(y = e^x\) at the point \(x = {@a@}\). The curve and the line are displayed in the following figure:

  1. We first specify \(x_0\) and \(f(x_0)\):

    \(x_0=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

    \(f(x_0)=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

  2. We now obtain the values of the slope at \(x_0\), i.e. \(m=\dfrac{df}{ dx} \bigg|_{ x_0}\) and the \(y\)-intercept \(f(x_0) - mx_0\):

    \(\dfrac{df}{ dx} \bigg|_{ x_0}=\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

    \(f(x_0) - mx_0 =\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]

  3. Finally, we use these values to obtain the equation of the tangent line:

    \(y =\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]][[feedback:prt5]]

generalfeedback.text:
We are asked to find the equation of the tangent line to the curve \(y = e^x\) at the point \(x = {@a@}\).

  1. First we specify that \(x_0 = {@a@}\) and \( f(x_0) = {@ta2@}.\)

  2. Then we obtain the values of \(\dfrac{df}{ dx} \bigg|_{ x_0}\) and \(f(x_0) - mx_0\):

    \(\dfrac{df}{dx} = e^x\) therefore \(\dfrac{df}{dx}\bigg|_{@a@} = e^{{@a@}}\) and \(f({@a@}) - {@ta3@}({@a@}) = {@ta4@} .\)

  3. Hence we obtain the equation of the tangent line: \(y= {@ta5@} .\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
